title: Log-Concave Density Estimation in Arbitrary Dimensions
text: package contains selection functions maximum likelihood estimation constraint log-concavity. mlelcd computes maximum likelihood estimator (specified via value data points). Output list class “LogConcDEAD” used input various auxiliary functions. hatA calculates difference sample covariance fitted covariance. dlcd evaluates estimated density particular point. dslcd evaluates smoothed version estimated density particular point. rlcd draws samples estimated density. rslcd draws samples smoothed version estimated density. interplcd interpolates estimated density grid plotting purposes. dmarglcd evaluates estimated marginal density integrating estimated density appropriate subspace. interpmarglcd evaluates marginal density estimate equally spaced points along axis plotting purposes. done integrating estimated density appropriate subspace. plot.LogConcDEAD produces plots maximum likelihood estimator, optionally using rgl package. print summary methods also available.

code: ## Some simple normal data, and a few plots  x <- matrix(rnorm(200),ncol=2) lcd <- mlelcd(x) g <- interplcd(lcd) par(mfrow=c(2,2), ask=TRUE) plot(lcd, g=g, type="c") plot(lcd, g=g, type="c", uselog=TRUE) plot(lcd, g=g, type="i") plot(lcd, g=g, type="i", uselog=TRUE)  ## Some plots of marginal estimates par(mfrow=c(1,1)) g.marg1 <- interpmarglcd(lcd, marg=1) g.marg2 <- interpmarglcd(lcd, marg=2) plot(lcd, marg=1, g.marg=g.marg1) plot(lcd, marg=2, g.marg=g.marg2)   ## generate some points from the fitted density generated <- rlcd(100, lcd) genmean <- colMeans(generated)  ## evaluate the fitted density mypoint <- c(0, 0) dlcd(mypoint, lcd, uselog=FALSE) mypoint <- c(10, 0) dlcd(mypoint, lcd, uselog=FALSE)  ## evaluate the marginal density dmarglcd(0, lcd, marg=1) dmarglcd(1, lcd, marg=2)

code: ## Some simple normal data, and a few plots  x <- matrix(rnorm(200),ncol=2) lcd <- mlelcd(x) g <- interplcd(lcd) par(mfrow=c(2,2), ask=TRUE) plot(lcd, g=g, type="c") plot(lcd, g=g, type="c", uselog=TRUE) plot(lcd, g=g, type="i") plot(lcd, g=g, type="i", uselog=TRUE)   ## Some plots of marginal estimates par(mfrow=c(1,1)) g.marg1 <- interpmarglcd(lcd, marg=1) g.marg2 <- interpmarglcd(lcd, marg=2) plot(lcd, marg=1, g.marg=g.marg1)  plot(lcd, marg=2, g.marg=g.marg2)    ## generate some points from the fitted density generated <- rlcd(100, lcd) genmean <- colMeans(generated)  ## evaluate the fitted density mypoint <- c(0, 0) dlcd(mypoint, lcd, uselog=FALSE) #> [1] 0.1243162 mypoint <- c(10, 0) dlcd(mypoint, lcd, uselog=FALSE) #> [1] 0  ## evaluate the marginal density dmarglcd(0, lcd, marg=1) #> [1] 0.3999072 dmarglcd(1, lcd, marg=2) #> [1] 0.2271997

title:
Evaluation of a log-concave maximum likelihood estimator at a
  point — dlcd
text: log-concave maximum likelihood estimate   \(\hat{f}_n\) satisfies \(\log \hat{f}_n = \bar{h}_y\) \(y \R^n\),   $$\bar{h}_y(x) = \inf \lbrace h(x) \colon h \textrm{ concave }, h(x_i)   \geq y_i \textrm{ } = 1, \ldots, n \rbrace.$$ Functions form may equivalently specified dividing   \(C_n\), convex hull data simplices \(C_j\)   \(j \J\) (triangles 2d, tetrahedra 3d etc), setting   $$f(x) = \exp\{b_j^T x - \beta_j\}$$   \(x \C_j\), \(f(x) = 0\) \(x \notin   C_n\).  estimated density zero outside convex   hull data. estimate may therefore evaluated finding appropriate   simplex \(C_j\), evaluating \(\exp\{b_j^T x -   \beta_j\}\) (\(x \notin C_n\), set \(f(x) = 0\)). examples, see mlelcd.

title:
Evaluation of a smoothed log-concave maximum likelihood estimator at given
  points — dslcd
text: smoothed log-concave maximum likelihood estimator fully automatic   nonparametric density estimator, obtained canonical smoothing    log-concave maximum likelihood estimator. precisely, equals convolution   \( \hat{f} * \phi_{d,\hat{}}\), \(\phi_{d,\hat{}}\) density function    d-dimensional multivariate normal covariance matrix \(\hat{}\).    Typically, \(\hat{}\) taken difference sample covariance    covariance fitted log-concave maximum likelihood density. Therefore, estimator    matches empirical mean empirical covariance. estimate evaluated numerically either Gaussian quadrature two dimensions,    higher dimensions, via combinatorial method proposed Grundmann Moeller (1978).   Details computational aspects can found Chen Samworth (2011). one    dimension, explicit expression can derived. See    logcondens information. examples, see mlelcd

text: log-concave maximum likelihood density estimator based data   \(X_1, \ldots, X_n\) function maximizes   $$\sum_{=1}^n w_i \log f(X_i)$$ subject constraint \(f\)   log-concave. ..d.~data, weights \(w_i\)   \(\frac{1}{n}\) \(\). function form \(\bar{h}_y\) \(y     \R^n\), $$\bar{h}_y(x)     = \inf \lbrace h(x) \colon h \textrm{ concave }, h(x_i) \geq y_i     \textrm{ } = 1, \ldots, n \rbrace.$$ Functions form may equivalently specified dividing   \(C_n\), convex hull data, simplices \(C_j\)   \(j \J\) (triangles 2d, tetrahedra 3d etc), setting   $$f(x) = \exp\{b_j^T x - \beta_j\}$$   \(x \C_j\), \(f(x) = 0\) \(x \notin   C_n\). function uses Shor's \(r\)-algorithm (iterative   subgradient-based procedure) minimize vectors \(y\)   \(R^n\) function $$\sigma(y) = -\frac{1}{n} \sum_{=1}^n y_i   + \int \exp(\bar{h}_y(x)) \, dx.$$  equivalent finding log-concave   maximum likelihood estimator, demonstrated Cule, Samworth   Stewart (2008). implementation Shor's \(r\)-algorithm based SolvOpt used. title: Compute the maximum likelihood estimator of a log-concave density — mlelcd
code: ## Some simple normal data, and a few plots  x <- matrix(rnorm(200),ncol=2) lcd <- mlelcd(x) g <- interplcd(lcd) par(mfrow=c(2,2), ask=TRUE) plot(lcd, g=g, type="c") plot(lcd, g=g, type="c", uselog=TRUE) plot(lcd, g=g, type="i") plot(lcd, g=g, type="i", uselog=TRUE)   ## 2D interactive plot (need rgl package, not run here) #  plot(lcd, type="r")   ## Some plots of marginal estimates par(mfrow=c(1,1)) g.marg1 <- interpmarglcd(lcd, marg=1) g.marg2 <- interpmarglcd(lcd, marg=2) plot(lcd, marg=1, g.marg=g.marg1)  plot(lcd, marg=2, g.marg=g.marg2)    ## generate some points from the fitted density ## via independent rejection sampling generated1 <- rlcd(100, lcd) colMeans(generated1) #> [1]  0.2094174 -0.1760564 ## via Metropolis-Hastings algorithm generated2 <- rlcd(100, lcd, "MH") colMeans(generated2) #> [1] 0.10072359 0.06037948  ## evaluate the fitted density mypoint <- c(0, 0) dlcd(mypoint, lcd, uselog=FALSE) #> [1] 0.1573178 mypoint <- c(1, 0) dlcd(mypoint, lcd, uselog=FALSE) #> [1] 0.1069506  ## evaluate the marginal density dmarglcd(0, lcd, marg=1) #> [1] 0.424504 dmarglcd(1, lcd, marg=2) #> [1] 0.2541608  ## evaluate the covariance matrix of the fitted density covariance <- cov.LogConcDEAD(lcd)  ## find the hat matrix for the smoothed log-concave that ## matches empirical mean and covariance A <- hatA(lcd)  ## evaluate the fitted smoothed log-concave density mypoint <- c(0, 0) dslcd(mypoint, lcd, A) #> [1] 0.1380299 mypoint <- c(1, 0) dslcd(mypoint, lcd, A) #> [1] 0.106271  ## generate some points from the fitted smoothed log-concave density generated <- rslcd(100, lcd, A)
